articles.headline: President Gives a Short Lifeline to Carmakers
articles.snippet: President Obama on Monday set out strict standards that the carmakers must meet to get more government aid.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Monday set out strict standards that the carmakers must meet to get more government aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama delivered an ultimatum to General Motors and Chrysler on Monday, telling them to adopt radical changes in short order or face bankruptcy  a move that came after a series of somber discussions in which he concluded that a controlled bankruptcy might be the best way to reorganize the two ailing auto giants.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Contracts Now Seen as Being Rewritable
articles.snippet: The depth of the recession and the use of taxpayer dollars to bail out companies have made it politically acceptable for overseers to tinker with employment agreements.
articles.abstract: The depth of the recession and the use of taxpayer dollars to bail out companies have made it politically acceptable for overseers to tinker with employment agreements.
articles.byline: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH and JONATHAN GLATER

articles.headline: G.M.’s Bondholders Speak in the Voice of the Aggrieved
articles.snippet: If there is any chance of keeping the company out of Chapter 11, odds are bondholders — and not just workers — will have to come to the table with an open mind.
articles.abstract: If there is any chance of keeping the company out of Chapter 11, odds are bondholders — and not just workers — will have to come to the table with an open mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama had scarcely outlined his plan to save General Motors and already, the big money was pushing back.

articles.headline: U.S. Sees a Smaller Future for G.M. Than G.M. Does
articles.snippet: President Obama said that even after further streamlining, the company might still need a trip through bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that even after further streamlining, the company might still need a trip through bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors has 60 days to fix a set of problems that have been decades in the making.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: A Pitched Battle for Turf Between the Bears and the Bulls
articles.snippet: The rift between these two Wall Street camps seems to be widening as uncertainty over the fate of banks, the Detroit carmakers, and the entire economy continues.
articles.abstract: The rift between these two Wall Street camps seems to be widening as uncertainty over the fate of banks, the Detroit carmakers, and the entire economy continues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time to buy stocks. No, wait  time to sell them.
